quote: The child is both a hope and a promise for mankind.
through_line: Running through today's brief is a question about relational identity — who we are in relation to those we raise, those we learn from, and those whose thinking we inherit. From children navigating AI to the neuroscience of rewiring the self, to a Japanese ethics of collective being, the thread is the same: identity is never fully individual.

articles.title: How to raise children in the age of AI
articles.pitch: The WEF lays out what parents and educators actually need to do — not fear AI, but build the capacities that AI can't replicate: curiosity, ethical reasoning, and emotional intelligence. Practical without being prescriptive.

articles.title: Children and AI: growing up with intelligent machines
articles.pitch: A companion piece looking at how children are already forming relationships with AI systems — and what that means for their development, their sense of agency, and their understanding of what it means to be human.

articles.title: Your brain is not a computer
articles.pitch: Against the dominant metaphor of mind as processor, this essay argues that the brain is better understood as a constantly rewiring biological system — one whose plasticity is not a feature but its fundamental nature. Quietly radical.

articles.title: Ningen: the Japanese concept of being human together
articles.pitch: In Japanese philosophy, personhood is not something you have but something that happens between people. Ningen — literally 'human space' — offers a relational ethics that sits in quiet contrast to Western individualism.
